text: [Music]
my name is Kevin Lynch I'm a staff
engineer on the site reliability team
lately I've been involved in bringing
kubernetes to the organization
Squarespace provides websites domains in
an e-commerce platform for all of our
customers worldwide
we're space runs out of a few
datacenters and everything was run on
virtual machines on VMware ESX servers
we were running into a problem with that
because we ended up spending a lot of
time provisioning machines for all any
new services that would come up or to
scale up an existing services we needed
a better way for our developers to
request and scale up their services one
of the most immediate benefits was our
service developers were able to ship
services without us even knowing about
it all without any sre involvement it
really drove a self-service model that
we which was what we really wanted
migrating our services from VMs to to
kubernetes has really impacted our our
deployment time in a positive way
introducing kubernetes has allowed that
process to be reduced by as much as 85
percent I'm not worried now if
kubernetes node goes down because I know
that our fleet will survive we have
enough capacity to for kubernetes to
automatically handle that we started
looking into replacing our graphite and
sensu clusters with prometheus and alert
manager that that required some amount
of changes to how we looked at and
observed our systems but it's been very
easy and very seamless transition from
that I think the CNC F has been really
great for kubernetes I think that's one
of the most important things about
kubernetes there's not one body
that one business is in charge of
kubernetes if someone is looking to roll
out kubernetes whether it's in your own
data center or even in the cloud I would
say just go for it you know it will be
so easy once you do it there's so much
more documentation out there and it it
just keeps growing and growing and
kubernetes isn't going away anytime soon
and the CN CF I think will help steward
that and for the years to come
